Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Developing Perspectives on Principal-Agent Theory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This dissertation combines qualitative analysis of semi-structured interviews with civic employees in three U.S. states with quantitative analysis of an original survey of public policy students to explore several research questions: How do bureaucratic agents shield themselves from political attacks? Under what circumstances do these agents rebel? How does this principal-agent problem affect the balance between principal and agent? The results will provide evidence on the social-psychological and/or organizational consequences of introducing intrusive actions into the civil service context.

This project examines what happens when civil service principals directly attack their bureaucratic agents. By exploiting differences across U.S. states in principal-on-agent attacks in the 2011-2014 period, this study describes the effect of working under "attack" on the behavior of state government bureaucrats. In particular, it examines the effect on retention, morale and recruitment in government organizations. This research also extends principal-agent theory to cover instances where the implicit contract between principal and agent is breached.

This will make important contributions to both sociology and public administration. First, the qualitative data will provide an opportunity to better understand workers within government bureaucracies by investigating individual and organizational behaviors and mechanisms workers employ to respond to conflict and threat. Second, from the public administration practitioner perspective, understanding variation in civic pressure in the state context will be important to developing recruitment and retention programs to ensure continued competitiveness for high quality labor.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation makes important contributions to both sociology and public administration. First, a successful study extends the principal-agent literature by investigating the empirical consequences of principal-on-agent attacks and theorizing about potential shifts in the balance between principal and agent. The changing nature of this legislative/bureaucratic relationship requires new data and theory in the means used to maintain stability and productivity in government service. My results provide new evidence suggesting that bureaucratic agents are motivated more by internal factors than by the guidance of their legislative principals. These results offer new data for teaching about principal-agent relationships and also an extension to the existing theory. Second, the collection and publication of these qualitative interviews provides an opportunity for researchers to better understand bureaucratic organizations by investigating the way that bureaucrats approach their jobs and respond to conflict and threat. All data from this project is available to interested third parties to broaden the basis for continued research in this area. Third, from the public administration practitioner perspective, this project provides an extended investigation into the workplace identity construction processes and behaviors of state government bureaucrats, which can be used for developing appropriate recruitment and retention programs to stabilize and prevent laborforce churning in government organizations. I have shared my findings with professional associations in both sociology and public administration to help advance our understanding of the changing relationship between politics and the civil service. Stability is at the core of American democracy; maintaining that stability, even in the face of changing conditions, is not just meaningful, but necessary.
